The <nav> element should be used to iden: The <nav> element should be used to identify groups of links that are intended to be used for website or page content navigation.
The <div> element should only be used if: The <div> element should only be used if the block is a design element with no semantic meaning.

Patterns are available from the <Link>Wo: Patterns are available from the <Link>WordPress.org Pattern Directory</Link>, bundled in the active theme, or created by users on this site. Only patterns created on this site can be synced.
Only images can be used as a background: Only images can be used as a background image.
The <main> element should be used for th: The <main> element should be used for the primary content of your document only.
Scale down the content to fit the space: Scale down the content to fit the space if it is too big. Content that is too small will have additional padding.
Do not adjust the sizing of the content. Content that is too large will be clipped, and content that is too small will have additional padding.
Fill the space by clipping what doesn't: Fill the space by clipping what doesn't fit.
Fit the content to the space without cli: Fit the content to the space without clipping.
Fill the space by stretching the content: Fill the space by stretching the content.
The block will stick to the scrollable a: The block will stick to the scrollable area of the parent %s block.
External images can be removed by the ex: External images can be removed by the external provider without warning and could even have legal compliance issues related to privacy legislation.
This image cannot be uploaded to your Me: This image cannot be uploaded to your Media Library, but it can still be inserted as an external image.
There is an error with your CSS structur: There is an error with your CSS structure.

The block will not move when the page is: The block will not move when the page is scrolled.
The block will stick to the top of the w: The block will stick to the top of the window instead of scrolling.

The <footer> element should represent a: The <footer> element should represent a footer for its nearest sectioning element (eg <section>, <article>, <main>, etc).
The <aside> element should represent a p: The <aside> element should represent a portion of a document whose content is only indirectly related to the document's main content.
The <article> element should represent a: The <article> element should represent a self-contained, syndicatable portion of the document.
The <section> element should represent a: The <section> element should represent a standalone portion of the document that can't be better represented by another element.
The <header> element should represent in: The <header> element should represent introductory content, typically a group of introductory or navigational aids.
Use left and right arrow keys to move th: Use left and right arrow keys to move through blocks
Customize the width for all elements tha: Customise the width for all elements that are assigned to the centre or wide columns.
